title: The Fifth and Sixth Trumpets
shortSummary: Revelation 9 describes the sounding of the fifth and sixth trumpets, unleashing terrifying judgments upon the earth. These judgments include the release of demonic locusts from the bottomless pit and a vast army of horsemen, bringing torment and death as a call to repentance. The chapter highlights human stubbornness in sin despite severe divine punishment.
timeline: Apocalyptic vision given to John, traditionally dated c. AD 95 during the late first century

keyCharacters.name: The Fifth Angel
keyCharacters.description: The angel who sounds the fifth trumpet and releases the locust-like tormentors from the bottomless pit.

keyCharacters.name: Abaddon/Apollyon
keyCharacters.description: The king of the locusts, described as the angel of the bottomless pit, whose name means 'Destroyer' in Hebrew and Greek.

keyCharacters.name: The Sixth Angel
keyCharacters.description: The angel who sounds the sixth trumpet and releases the four bound angels to lead a massive army to kill a third of mankind.

keyCharacters.name: The Four Angels Bound at Euphrates
keyCharacters.description: Angelic beings restrained until the sixth trumpet, then released to execute judgment by leading a vast army.

definitions.definition: A deep abyss or prison for demonic beings, symbolizing a place of confinement and judgment.
In this context, supernatural creatures resembling locusts that bring torment but not death, symbolizing demonic tormentors.
An expression of divine judgment and calamity, signaling increasing severity of God's wrath.
A mark of divine protection on believers, indicating ownership by God and exemption from certain judgments.

outline.heading: The Fifth Trumpet: The Locusts from the Bottomless Pit
outline.description: The fifth angel sounds, releasing a star fallen from heaven who opens the bottomless pit. From the smoke come locust-like creatures empowered to torment those without God's seal for five months, led by their king Abaddon/Apollyon. This judgment is severe but limited, emphasizing God's control and the torment of unrepentant sinners.

outline.heading: Declaration of the First Woe
outline.description: John announces that the first woe has passed, but two more woes remain, heightening the sense of impending divine judgment.

outline.heading: The Sixth Trumpet: The Release of Four Angels and the Army
outline.description: The sixth angel sounds, and four angels bound at the Euphrates are released to lead a massive army of 200 million horsemen. This army kills a third of mankind by fire, smoke, and brimstone, demonstrating God's sovereign judgment on the earth.

outline.heading: The Unrepentant Remnant
outline.description: Despite these devastating judgments, the survivors refuse to repent of idolatry, murder, sorcery, sexual immorality, and theft, revealing the hardness of human hearts and the necessity of God's final intervention.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and the reality of divine judgment, motivating a life of holiness and obedience to God.
Trust in God's sovereign control over evil, even when facing spiritual warfare or trials, knowing He limits the power of the enemy.
Examine your heart for areas of unrepentance and idolatry, responding with genuine repentance and faith in Christ.
Pray for protection under God's seal and for perseverance through trials, relying on His grace and mercy.

keyVerses.text: And it was commanded them that they should not hurt the grass of the earth, neither any green thing, neither any tree; but only those men which have not the seal of God in their foreheads.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's protection over His people amid judgment, emphasizing the importance of being sealed by God.

keyVerses.text: And in those days shall men seek death, and shall not find it; and shall desire to die, and death shall flee from them.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the intense torment of God's judgment and the desperation of those who reject Him.

keyVerses.text: And the rest of the men which were not killed by these plagues yet repented not of the works of their hands, that they should not worship devils, and idols of gold, and silver, and brass, and stone, and of wood: which neither can see, nor hear, nor walk:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals human stubbornness and the refusal to repent despite severe judgment, warning believers to respond rightly to God's discipline.
